clues.clue: Boyle’s law (variables & relation).
clues.answer: P ∝ 1/V at constant T and n (P1V1 = P2V2).

clues.clue: Charles’s law (variables & relation).
clues.answer: V ∝ T at constant P and n (V1/T1 = V2/T2), T in Kelvin.

clues.clue: Gay-Lussac’s law (variables & relation).
clues.answer: P ∝ T at constant V and n (P1/T1 = P2/T2), T in Kelvin.

clues.clue: Avogadro’s law (variables & relation).
clues.answer: V ∝ n at constant P and T.

clues.clue: Combined gas law—write it.
Write the ideal gas equation.
Common values of R (give one with units).
Why do we say 'ideal gas'?
clues.answer: Model assumes point particles with elastic collisions, no intermolecular forces.

clues.clue: If P and n are constant, how does V change with T?
clues.answer: Directly proportional; V increases as T increases.

clues.clue: At fixed volume, T increases—what happens to P and why?
clues.answer: P increases; faster molecules collide more frequently and forcefully with container walls.

clues.clue: Which unit must temperature be in for gas law calculations?
If cylinder is cooled without gas loss, what happens to pressure?
If you halve the volume of a gas at constant T, what happens to pressure?
If you double moles at constant P and T, what happens to volume?
Name one reason ideal gas assumptions break down clinically.
clues.answer: High pressures/low temperatures cause non-ideal behavior (intermolecular forces, finite volume).

clues.clue: Define a mole in one sentence.
clues.answer: Amount of substance containing Avogadro’s number of particles (6.022×10^23).

clues.clue: Empirical formula of C6H12O6.
Strong acid definition.
Equilibrium at the molecular level means what?
clues.answer: Forward and reverse reaction rates are equal.

clues.clue: Activation energy is what?
clues.answer: Minimum energy required to initiate a reaction.

clues.clue: Convert 25 °C to Kelvin.
log10(1×10^−4) equals what?
If [OH−] = 5×10^−5, compute pOH (2 sig figs).
Kw at 25 °C equals?
State variable not in ideal gas law directly.
Why do we ignore intermolecular attractions in ideal gas model?
clues.answer: Assumption simplifies; works well at low P and high T.

clues.clue: Which increases collision frequency: ↑T or ↓V (at constant n)?
Doubling T in Kelvin at constant V does what to P?
State the combined gas law constraint on n.
clues.answer: n must be constant (closed system, no gas added/removed).

finalJeopardy.clue: Cylinder at 300 K and 2000 psi is moved to 240 K with no gas loss. Approximate new pressure (assume ideal, constant V).
